summary_points: 1.  Vulcan Materials Company projects a 19% increase in Adjusted EBITDA for 2025, driven primarily by pricing and operational efficiencies, despite only a projected 3-5% increase in aggregate shipments.
2.  The company's total assets increased significantly year-over-year, rising from $14,545.7 million in 2023 to $17,104.8 million in 2024 (a 17.6% increase).
3.  Vulcan anticipates $18.5 million in self-insurance payments in 2025, and an additional $120.1 million in minimum self-insurance payments over the following five years.
1. Ametek Inc. achieved record sales of $6,941.2 million in 2024, a 5.2% increase year-over-year, despite a 2% organic sales decline.
2.  The company's net debt-to-capital ratio significantly improved to 15.0% by December 31, 2024, down from 25.0% at the end of 2023.
3. Ametek Inc. established a $2.3 billion commercial paper program in January 2025 and has a new $1.25 billion share repurchase authorization effective February 7, 2025.
1. Ball Corporation's net sales decreased by $267 million year-over-year in 2024 to $11.795 billion, primarily due to lower sales prices and lost volume from a 2023 facility fire.
2.  The company recorded a $420 million charge in 2024 related to its aluminum cups business impairment and anticipates forming a strategic partnership to deconsolidate this business in early 2025.
3.  Ball Corporation expects to complete a buyout of its U.K. pension plan by February 20, 2027, resulting in a non-cash settlement charge.
1. Ball Corporation divested its aerospace business in February 2024, realizing a pre-tax gain of $4.61 billion.

2.  Despite a $267 million net sales decrease in 2024, primarily due to lower sales prices and lost volume, Ball Corporation increased its cash reserves to $931 million by December 31, 2024, from $710 million at the end of 2023.

3.  Ball Corporation anticipates a strategic partnership and deconsolidation of its aluminum cups business in early 2025, and faces ongoing litigation with Crown, with unpredictable outcomes expected from oral arguments in 2025.
1. Quanta Services completed three acquisitions in 2024 and 2025 totaling approximately $3.16 billion, including potential contingent payments.
2.  Quanta's net income increased by 21.5% year-over-year in 2024, exceeding its revenue growth of 13.4%.
3.  Quanta's cash and cash equivalents decreased significantly to $741.96 million by the end of 2024, from $1,290.25 million at the end of 2023.

1. Quanta Services' 2024 revenue increased by 13.4% year-over-year, driven primarily by growth in Renewable Energy and Electric Power segments, offset by a decrease in the Underground and Infrastructure segment.
2.  Quanta's cash and cash equivalents decreased significantly in 2024, from $1,290.25 million to $741.96 million.

3.  As of February 20, 2025, Quanta has $9.5 billion in outstanding performance bonds and is assessing the impact of new SEC climate disclosure rules (currently stayed) and upcoming FASB expense disclosure updates.
1. Teradyne's 10% equity stake in Technoprobe, acquired in May 2024 for $524.1 million, had a $105 million unrealized loss as of December 31, 2024.
2. Semiconductor Test revenue increased by 8.5% year-over-year in 2024, while Robotics revenue declined by 2.8%.
3. Teradyne plans to repurchase up to $400 million of its common stock in 2025, but repurchased significantly fewer shares in 2024 ($199.4 million) compared to 2023 ($400.5 million).

1. Teradyne's 2024 total revenue increased by 8.5% to $2,819,880,000, driven by Semiconductor Test segment growth, but a stronger U.S. dollar is projected to negatively impact Robotics revenue in 2025.
2.  As of December 31, 2024, Teradyne's $494.5 million equity method investment in Technoprobe had a $105 million lower fair value ($389.5 million).
3.  Teradyne's 2024 share repurchases totaled $199.4 million (1.7 million shares), significantly less than the $400.5 million (3.9 million shares) in 2023.

1. Pool Corporation's 2024 net sales decreased by 4% year-over-year to $5.3 billion, primarily due to softer discretionary product sales for new pool construction and remodeling, impacted by macroeconomic conditions.
2.  Operating income for 2024 decreased by 17% year-over-year to $617.2 million, resulting in an operating margin of 11.6%, down from 13.5% in 2023.
3.  Pool Corporation projects 2025 diluted earnings per share to be in the range of $11.08 to $11.58, including an estimated $0.08 tax benefit.

1. Pool Corporation's 2024 net sales decreased 4% year-over-year to $5.3 billion, primarily due to softer discretionary product sales impacted by macroeconomic conditions, while maintenance product sales remained stable.
2.  Operating income for 2024 decreased 17% year-over-year to $617.2 million, resulting in an operating margin of 11.6%, down from 13.5% in 2023.
3.  Pool Corporation provided 2025 diluted EPS guidance in the range of $11.08 to $11.58, including an estimated $0.08 tax benefit.
1. Fiserv's total revenue increased 7% year-over-year in 2024, reaching $20,456 million, but this growth was partially offset by negative impacts from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations.
2. A $595 million non-cash impairment charge was recorded in 2024 due to the non-renewal of the Wells Fargo Merchant Services alliance.
3. Fiserv anticipates completing two acquisitions in Q1 2025 for a total of approximately $360 million.
1. Fiserv's total revenue increased by 7% in 2024, reaching $1.363 billion more than in 2023.
2.  Fiserv expects to complete two acquisitions (CCV and Payfare) for $360 million in Q1 2025.
3.  A $595 million non-cash impairment charge was recorded in 2024 due to a decline in the value of its investment in Wells Fargo Merchant Services, expiring April 1, 2025.
1. Baxter International Inc. completed the sale of its Kidney Care business to Carlyle on January 31, 2025, for approximately $3.4 billion in net, after-tax proceeds, exceeding initial expectations.
2.  In 2024, Baxter's full-year sales from continuing operations increased by 3% to $10.64 billion, while adjusted diluted EPS from continuing operations reached $1.89, exceeding prior guidance.

3. Baxter projects full-year 2025 sales growth from continuing operations of 5% to 6% on a reported basis and adjusted earnings from continuing operations, before special items, of $2.45 to $2.55 per diluted share.
1. Baxter International Inc. completed the sale of its Kidney Care business to Carlyle for approximately $3.4 billion in net, after-tax proceeds on January 31, 2025, exceeding previous expectations.
2.  For the full year 2024, Baxter reported adjusted diluted EPS from continuing operations of $1.89, compared to $1.70 in 2023, an 11% increase.

3. Baxter's 2025 financial outlook projects sales growth from continuing operations of 5% to 6% on a reported basis and adjusted earnings from continuing operations of $2.45 to $2.55 per diluted share.

1. Builders FirstSource, Inc. reported a year-over-year decrease in net sales of 8.0% for Q4 2024, primarily due to lower core organic sales and commodity deflation, partially offset by acquisitions and an extra selling day.
2.  For the full year 2024, the company repurchased $1.5 billion of its common stock, reducing total shares outstanding by 6.8%.

3.  The company forecasts net sales in the range of $16.5 billion to $17.5 billion for 2025, with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 11.5% to 13.0%, and free cash flow between $600 million and $1.0 billion (assuming commodity prices between $380 and $430 per mbf).
1. Builders FirstSource, Inc.'s fourth-quarter 2024 net sales decreased by 8.0% year-over-year to $3.8 billion, primarily due to lower core organic sales and commodity deflation.
2.  For the full year 2024, the company repurchased $1.5 billion of its common stock, reducing total shares outstanding by 6.8%.
3.  The company projects net sales in the range of $16.5 billion to $17.5 billion and free cash flow between $600 million and $1.0 billion for 2025.
1. Quanta Services, Inc. reported record revenues of $23.67 billion for the full year 2024, exceeding 2023's $20.88 billion.
2.  For the full year ending December 31, 2025, Quanta expects double-digit revenue growth, projecting revenues between $26.60 billion and $27.10 billion.
3.  As of December 31, 2024, Quanta had a total backlog of $34.54 billion, and anticipates achieving record backlog in 2025.

1. Quanta Services, Inc. reported record fourth-quarter and full-year 2024 results on February 20, 2025, including consolidated revenues of $6.55 billion for Q4 2024 (compared to $5.78 billion in Q4 2023) and $23.67 billion for the full year (compared to $20.88 billion in 2023).
2.  Quanta's full-year 2025 revenue guidance projects double-digit growth, ranging from $26.60 billion to $27.10 billion, and anticipates achieving record backlog.

3.  Beginning March 31, 2025, Quanta will report its results under two segments: Electric Infrastructure Solutions and Underground Utility and Infrastructure Solutions, reflecting a convergence of industry dynamics and customer needs.
1. Hasbro's full-year 2024 revenue declined 17%, but excluding the eOne divestiture, revenue decreased only 7%.
2.  Adjusted operating profit increased by $362 million year-over-year in 2024, resulting in an adjusted operating margin of 20.3%, a 10.8-point increase.
3. Hasbro forecasts slightly increased total revenue for 2025 in constant currency, with an adjusted operating margin projected at 21%-22% and adjusted EBITDA between $1.1 billion and $1.15 billion.
1. Hasbro's full-year 2024 revenue declined 17%, but excluding the eOne divestiture, revenue only decreased 7%.
2.  Adjusted operating profit for full-year 2024 increased by $362 million compared to the prior year, resulting in an adjusted operating margin increase of 10.8 percentage points.
3. Hasbro's 2025 outlook predicts slightly increased total revenue in constant currency, with an adjusted operating margin of 21%-22% and adjusted EBITDA between $1.1 billion and $1.15 billion.
1. LKQ Corp's Q4 2024 revenue decreased by 4.1% year-over-year to $3.4 billion, while full-year 2024 revenue increased by 3.5% to $14.4 billion.
2.  Diluted earnings per share (EPS) for Q4 2024 was $0.60, down 13% year-over-year, and full-year 2024 diluted EPS was $2.62, a decrease of 25.4% year-over-year.
3.  Management anticipates 0% to 2% organic revenue growth for parts and services in 2025, with diluted EPS projected to be between $2.91 and $3.21 and adjusted diluted EPS between $3.40 and $3.70.
1. LKQ Corp's fourth-quarter 2024 revenue decreased by 4.1% year-over-year to $3.4 billion, while full-year 2024 revenue increased by 3.5% to $14.4 billion.

2.  Diluted earnings per share (EPS) decreased significantly year-over-year in the fourth quarter of 2024 (13%), and for the full year 2024 (25.4%),  while adjusted diluted EPS showed smaller decreases of 4.8% and 9.1% respectively.
3.  Management anticipates 0% to 2% organic revenue growth for parts and services in 2025, with diluted EPS projected to be between $2.91 and $3.21, and adjusted diluted EPS between $3.40 and $3.70.
1. CenterPoint Energy's 2024 non-GAAP earnings per diluted share increased 8% year-over-year to $1.62.
2.  The company increased its 10-year capital plan by $500 million to $47.5 billion (as of February 20, 2025), largely for Houston grid resiliency.
3.  CenterPoint Energy's Houston Electric service territory projects a near 50% increase in electricity demand by 2031.
1. CenterPoint Energy's non-GAAP earnings increased by 8% year-over-year in Q4 2024.
2.  A $500 million increase to CenterPoint Energy's 10-year capital plan (through 2030) will fund grid resiliency improvements in Houston.
3. Houston Electric projects a nearly 50% increase in electricity demand by 2031.
1. Targa Resources Corp. reported record full-year 2024 adjusted EBITDA of $4.1 billion, a 17% increase compared to 2023, driven by record Permian volumes.
2.  For the fourth quarter of 2024, adjusted EBITDA increased by 5% sequentially, reaching $1.1 billion, primarily due to higher volumes across G&P and L&T systems.

3. Targa estimates record full-year 2025 adjusted EBITDA between $4.65 billion and $4.85 billion (midpoint representing a 15% increase over 2024),  and plans to increase its annual common dividend to $4.00 per share.

1. Targa Resources Corp. reported record full-year 2024 adjusted EBITDA of $4.1 billion, a 17% increase over 2023, and projects record full-year 2025 adjusted EBITDA between $4.65 billion and $4.85 billion (a 15% increase from 2024).

2.  As of December 31, 2024, Targa had total consolidated debt of $14,174.6 million and total consolidated liquidity of approximately $2.0 billion; however,  a new $3.5 billion revolving credit facility was secured in February 2025, increasing pro forma liquidity to approximately $2.8 billion.

3.  Targa anticipates completing several expansion projects, including the Delaware Express pipeline (operational start in Q3 2026), Train 12 fractionator (Q1 2027), and GPMT LPG Export Expansion (Q3 2027), requiring $2.6 billion to $2.8 billion in net growth capital expenditures in 2025.
1. NXP's 2024 revenue decreased 5% year-over-year to $12.6 billion, while its operating margin fell from 41% to 37%.

2.  As of February 20, 2025, NXP has $5 billion in cash and cash equivalents, but anticipates $100 million in restructuring charges and faces potential legal losses up to $280 million (after insurance).
3. NXP plans to spend $1.175 billion on three acquisitions in 2025 and has committed $16.125 billion to VSMC through 2044.
1. NXP's revenue decreased by 5% year-over-year in 2024, totaling $12,614 million.
2. NXP plans to acquire three companies for a combined $1,175 million in cash, with closings expected in 2025.
3.  NXP's legal proceedings accrual increased significantly to $281 million in 2024, with potential additional losses of up to $280 million, partially offsettable by insurance reimbursements.
1. On February 20, 2025, Parker-Hannifin Corp completed a registered offering of €700 million in 2.900% Senior Notes due 2030, intending to use the proceeds to repay its 1.125% Senior Notes due 2025.
2.  The offering of €700 million in Senior Notes, represents a significant financial event for Parker-Hannifin Corp in 2025.
3. The Notes include provisions for optional redemption prior to February 1, 2030, and mandatory repurchase at 101% of principal plus accrued interest if a change of control and a rating event occur.
1. On February 20, 2025, Parker-Hannifin Corp completed a registered offering of €700 million in 2.900% Senior Notes due 2030, intending to use the proceeds to repay its 1.125% Senior Notes due 2025.

2.  The company may redeem some or all of the 2.900% Senior Notes due 2030 before February 1, 2030, at prices described in the prospectus supplement, or at 100% of principal plus accrued interest afterward.
3.  If a change of control event and a rating event occur, the company will be required to offer to purchase the notes at 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued interest.
1. Mohawk Industries' 2024 net sales decreased by $300 million compared to 2023,  primarily due to unfavorable pricing and exchange rates.
2.  The company swung from a $439.5 million net loss in 2023 to a $517.7 million net profit in 2024.
3.  Mohawk anticipates $65 to $80 million in restructuring costs over 2025 and 2026.
1. Mohawk Industries swung from a net loss of $439.5 million in 2023 to a net profit of $517.7 million in 2024.
2.  The company expects to spend an additional $65–$80 million on restructuring in 2025 and 2026, beyond the $140 million already spent in 2024.
3. As of December 31, 2024, Mohawk faces 80 pending claims and 9 additional claims related to a loss contingency,  plus a €1.0 billion tax dispute with the Belgian Tax Authority.
1. EPAM Systems, Inc. reported Q4 2024 revenues of $1.248 billion, a 7.9% year-over-year increase, and full-year 2024 revenues of $4.728 billion, a 0.8% year-over-year increase.

2.  Full-year 2024 GAAP diluted EPS increased by 11.0% year-over-year to $7.84, while non-GAAP diluted EPS increased by 2.5% to $10.86,  partially offset by a higher effective tax rate due to government incentives.

3. EPAM expects 2025 full-year revenue growth to be in the range of 10.0% to 14.0% (1.0% to 5.0% organically and in constant currency), with GAAP income from operations as a percentage of revenue between 9.0% and 10.0%, and non-GAAP income from operations between 14.5% and 15.5% of revenue.

1. EPAM Systems, Inc. reported full-year 2024 revenues of $4.728 billion, a 0.8% year-over-year increase,  driven partially by a $68.8 million benefit from Polish research and development government incentives.
2.  For the full year 2025, EPAM expects revenue growth in the range of 10.0% to 14.0% (reported) and 1.0% to 5.0% on an organic constant currency basis.
3.  EPAM's cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash decreased by $752.7 million (36.8%) year-over-year to $1.290 billion as of December 31, 2024, primarily due to acquisition payments.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$638,772,436.56 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 19, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 19, 2025,  21,016,911 Class A shares and 10,368,673 Class B shares were repurchased at a high price of US$30.31 and US$35.01 respectively.
3.  News Corp's stock repurchase program, announced in previous filings and ongoing as of February 20, 2025, aims to enhance shareholder value.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$638,772,436.56 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 19, 2025, under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 19, 2025, 21,016,911 Class A shares and 10,368,673 Class B shares were repurchased at prices ranging from US$14.88 to US$30.69 (Class A) and US$15.17 to US$35.25 (Class B).

3. News Corp intends to continue repurchasing its Class A and Class B common stock from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors; however, the filing includes a disclaimer stating that future results may differ materially from expectations.
1. CrowdStrike's Chief Security Officer, Shawn Henry, will retire from his executive role on March 31, 2025, transitioning to Executive Advisor to the CEO.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Mr. Henry will no longer participate in CrowdStrike's Corporate Incentive Plan and Leadership Incentive Plan.
3. This 8-K filing from February 14, 2025, reports the departure of a named executive officer.

1. Yum! Brands terminated 538 restaurants in Turkey (284 KFC and 254 Pizza Hut) in January 2025 due to franchisee non-compliance, incurring $59 million in charges in 2024 and an additional $18 million in unallocated franchise revenue charges.

2.  The company faces potential material financial impacts from a $2.5 billion tax dispute ($2.1 billion underpayment plus $418 million in penalties) for fiscal year 2014, currently under appeal, and a potential $130 million penalty in India, pending court hearings in March and April 2025.

3.  Yum! Brands acquired 216 KFC restaurants in the U.K. and Ireland for $177 million in April 2024 and has future lease payments due from franchisees totaling approximately $650 million as of December 31, 2024.

1. Robert E. Smith was appointed Executive Vice President, Chief Legal Officer and Chief Development Officer of Pinnacle West and APS, effective immediately, while Shirley A. Baum was promoted to Senior Vice President and General Counsel of both companies; Smith plans to retire from his officer positions on August 1, 2025.
2.  This 8-K filing, dated February 19, 2025, concerns personnel changes at Pinnacle West Capital Corporation and Arizona Public Service Company.
3. The stated purpose of these personnel changes is to ensure a smooth transition of Mr. Smith's duties and responsibilities before his retirement in August 2025.
